In 1993, the Hawaii Supreme Court ruled that, indeed, denial of same-sex marriage amounted to discrimination on the basis of sex and sexual orientation.

The Supreme Court has held that this "full faith and credit" provision covers divorce--otherwise, you might have to get re-divorced from your former spouse if you moved to a new state.
The Vermont Supreme Court ruled this week that gay couples are entitled to the same "benefits and protections" as heterosexual married couples.
The Vermont Supreme Court ruled this week that gay couples are entitled to the same "benefits and protections" as heterosexual married couples.

With reasoning similar to that of the Hawaii courts, the Vermont Supreme Court determined that the legislature "was constitutionally required to extend to same-sex couples the common benefits and protections that flow from marriage under Vermont law."

In both states, gay couples sued, asserting that the ban on same-sex marriage deprived them of equal protection: They argued that it blocked their access to the same rights and obligations that heterosexual couples are granted through marriage, including health and pension benefits, inheritance rights, joint decision-making power, and shared parental and financial responsibilities.
